introduction.p: Study of the rate of change of position x gave us velocity v_x. We apply the same methods to study the rate of change of v_x. Therefore, we define an average acceleration and an instantaneous acceleration. For a motion on the x axis, we will denote instantaneous acceleration by symbol a_x and average acceleration by a_{\text{av},x}.

subsection.title: Average Acceleration
subsection.p:
The average rate of change of velocity during an interval from t_i to t_f can be obtained by dividing the change in velocity by the interval. Let v_{i,x} be the velocity at t_i and v_{f,x} be the velocity at t_f, then average acceleration, a_{\text{av},x}, will be
a_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{v_{f,x} - v_{i,x}}{ t_f - t_i}.
We often write this as
a_{\text{av},x} = \dfrac{\Delta v_x}{ \Delta t},
where \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} and \Delta t = t_f - t_i.

subsection.title: Instantaneous Acceleration
subsection.p: Often we want acceleration at a particular instant. What we mean by this is the average acceleration between that instant, say t and an instant very close to t, e.g., a tiny amount of time later than t, which we can indicate by t + \Delta t . How close to t should the instant t + \Delta t be? The answer is as close to t as possible. This is the notion of infinetismal interval.

Denoting the instantaneous acceleration for a motion along the x axis by the symbol a_x , we write this special averaging formally as
a_x = \dfrac{v_x\left(\text{at } (t+\Delta t)\right) - v_x\left(\text{at } t\right)}{\Delta t},
for t+\Delta t as close to t as possible. Since a_x is a ratio of a change in v_x to a change in t it can be computed by the slope of v_x versus t plot.

subsection.title: Graphical Definition of Acceleration
subsection.p:
Since the slope of a function is the rate of change of that function, the rate of change of velocity at a particular instant can be obtained from the slope of the tangent of the velocity versus time plot. We can take this as defining acceleration a_x for one-dimensional motion on the x axis.
a_x = \text{ slope of tangent to }v_x\text{ versus }t.
If the plot of v_x versus t is linear, i.e., a straight line, then the tangent line is same as the line of the plot, hence a_x is just the slope of the line.

figure.caption: The slope of v_x versus t plot gives the acceleration a_x . Since the plot is linear, the slope is same for all instants plotted. In (a) a_x = 1.0 \text{ m/s}^2 and in (b) a_x = - 0.75 \text{ m/s}^2.

subsection.p: But, if the plot of v_x versus t is curved, then you would draw a tangent line at the instant of interest, and compute the slope of the tangent line to get a_x .

figure.caption: The slope of v_x versus t plot gives the acceleration a_x . Since the plot is not linear, we need to first draw a tangent line at the instant we want the acceleration value. The figure illustrates a_x at t = 4\text{ sec}, where the slope of the tangent line is a_x = (4-(-1))/(5-3) = 2.5\text{ m/s}^2 .

exercise.title: Using slope of v_x to compute a_x

statement.p: From the v_x versus t plot in , find a_x at the following instants: (a) t = 1\text{ sec}, (b) t = 3\text{ sec} , and (c) t = 3.75\text{ sec} .

solution.p: (a) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 1\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is clearly zero. Therefore, a_x (\text{at }t=1\text{ sec}) = 0.

(b) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 3\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is obtained by picking two points on the line between t = 2\text{ sec} and t = 3.5\text{ sec}. We pick points at t = 2\text{ sec} and t = 3\text{ sec} to obtain
a_x = \dfrac{0 - 4\text{ m/s}}{3\text{ s}-2\text{ s}} = -4\text{ m/s}^2.

(b) The v_x versus t plot through the time when t = 3.75\text{ sec} is a straight line. Therefore, a_x will simply be slope of this part of the plot. The slope of this line is obtained by picking two points on the line between t = 3.5\text{ sec} and t = 4.0\text{ sec}. We pick points at t = 3.5\text{ sec} and t = 4\text{ sec} to obtain
a_x = \dfrac{0 - (-2)\text{ m/s}}{4\text{ s}-3.5\text{ s}} = 4\text{ m/s}^2.

subsection.title: \Delta v_x from a_x Graphically
subsection.p: We have learned that area under v_x versus t corresponds to change in x. Similarly, we can get \ Delta v_x from area under the curve of a_x versus t as illustrated in .
The area under the curve is the area between the graph and a_x=0 line. Therefore, for positive a_x we get positive area and for negative a_x we get netative area.

figure.caption: The area under the curve to get \Delta v_x from a_x versus t plot. The area for the curve when a_x \gt 0 is positive, as between t=0 and t= 2\text{ sec} and the area for the curve when a_x \lt 0 is negative, as between t= 2\text{ sec} and t= 4\text{ sec}.

exercise.title: Compute \Delta v_x from a_x versus t plot

statement.p: A ball is initially ( t=0 ) moving at v_x = 3\text{ m/s}. The acceleration of the ball at different times are as shown in the a_x versus t plot in . Find v_x at (a) t = 1\text{ sec} , (b) t = 2\text{ sec} , and (c) t = 4\text{ sec} .

solution.p:
(a) From the area-under-curve we can find the change in v_x during t= 0 to t = 1\text{ sec}. Adding this change to the v_x at t= 0 will give us the v_x at t=1\text{ sec}.
\Delta v_x = \dfrac{1}{2}\times 4 \times 1 = 2\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=1\text{ sec}:
v_x(\text{ at }t=1\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=0\ ) + \Delta v_x = 5\text{ m/s}.

(b) The area-under-the-curve during t= 1\text{ sec} to t = 2\text{ sec} is zero. Hence the velocity does not change over this interval, i.e., \Delta v_x = 0 .
v_x(\text{ at }t=2\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=1\text{ sec } ) + \Delta v_x = 5\text{ m/s}.

(c) From the area-under-curve we can find the change in t= 2\text{ sec} to t = 4\text{ sec}. Adding this change to the v_x at t= 2\text{ sec} will give us the v_x at t=4\text{ sec}.
\Delta v_x = -2 \times (4-2) = -4\text{ m/s}.
Therefore, v_x at t=4\text{ sec}:
v_x(\text{ at }t=4\text{ sec }) = v_x(\text{ at }t=2\text{ sec } ) + \Delta v_x = 1\text{ m/s}.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Analytic Definition of Acceleration
subsection.p: The derivative of velocity with respect to time gives the rate at which velocity changes. That is, acceleration a_x on the x axis is the derivative of the velocity v_x .

statement.p: In theoretical work you might find that you are given position as a function x(t) . For example, a block attached to a spring oscillates with its position x(t) = (5 \text{ cm}) \cos( 2\pi t), where t is in seconds. If you plot this x versus t , you will notice that the block moves between x = - 5 cm and x = 5 cm, repeating a complete cycle every second.
(a) What is the velocity of this block at (i) t = 0.25 s, (ii) t = 0.5 s, and (iii) t = 0.75 s.
(b) What is the acceleration of this block at (a) t = 0.25 s, (b) t = 0.5 s, and (c) t = 0.75 s.

solution.title: (a)
solution.p: Taking the derivative of given x(t) and then evaluating the result at the requires times should give us the answers.

solution.title: (b)
solution.p: Taking the derivative of v_x and then evaluating the result at the requires times should give us the answers.

subsection.title: (Calculus) Change in Velocity from Acceleration Analytically
subsection.p: The inverse problem of obtaining change in velocity, \Delta v_x, from a known acceleration, a_x(t) , is a similar problem of going from v_x to \Delta x. Therefore, the math is similar.

The inverse of Eq. gives the change in velocity \Delta v_x = v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} when we integrate acceleration a_x .
\Delta v_x \equiv v_{f,x} - v_{i,x} = \int_{t_i}^{t_f}\ a_x(t)\, dt.
